newsitem.title: USA: Asian, Latam crudes take center stage in US Gulf.
newsitem.headline: Asian, Latam crudes take center stage in US Gulf.

text.p: Asian and Latin American crudes took center stage in U.S. foreign crude trading on Friday amid the continued tight trans-Atlantic arbitrage, traders said.
A major U.S. refiner picked up Malaysian Tapis and Miri crudes from a European major at around 10 cents and 23 cents, respectively, over benchmark West Texas Intermediate/Cushing, traders said.
The deal extends a recent series of U.S. transactions involving Asian grades.

A Swiss trading company was still offering a small piece of prompt Indonesian Widuri crude on the U.S. Gulf Coast. Several refiners said the crude's high pour point would make it a hard sell in the U.S. market.
Elsewhere, Ecuadoran state oil company Petroecuador raised the price differentials by 10 cents a barrel for Oriente for most customers effective August 1, a trade source said.
Only those price differentials that are based on WTI were affected, the source said.
The new fob formula prices are as follows:
US Gulf Coast/East Coast/Caribbean WTI -$5.20 WTI -$5.30

The formula for the U.S. West Coast and Pacific Central America were unchanged at $2.56 and $2.51, respectively, under Alaska North Slope Long Beach. The formula for Asian customers was also unchanged at Oman minus $2.50 a barrel.
Separately, a U.S. refiner on Friday bought an Oriente spot cargo from a trader for September 1-10 at around $3.00 a barrel under WTI on a cif basis for the U.S. East Coast.
The same trader moved two more Oriente cargoes on Thursday, one for the U.S. Gulf at a $3.07 a barrel discount, and another for Peru at around $3.00-05 a barrel cif Peru.
Elsewhere in the region, a U.S. major was heard to have sold part of a Canadon Seco cargo to a U.S. refiner for mid-September at around $1.40-50 a barrel under WTI.
